name.text: 3.6.3.1 Proper fractions with repeated linear factors

questiontext.text:
Proper fractions with repeated linear factors


Sometimes a linear factor appears more than once. For example in

\(\dfrac{1}{x^2+2x+1}=\dfrac{1}{(x+1)(x+1)}\) which equals \(\dfrac{1}{(x+1)^2}\)

the factor \((x+1)\) occurs twice. We call it a repeated linear factor. The repeated linear factor \((x+1)^2\) produces two partial fractions of the form \(\dfrac{A}{x+1} + \dfrac{B}{(x+1)^2}\). In general, a repeated linear factor of the form \((ax+b)^2\) generates two partial fractions of the form

\[\dfrac{A}{ax+b} + \dfrac{B}{(ax+b)^2}\]

This is reasonable since the sum of two such fractions always gives rise to a proper fraction:

\[\dfrac{A}{ax+b} + \dfrac{B}{(ax+b)^2}=\dfrac{A(ax+b)}{(ax+b)^2}+\dfrac{B}{(ax+b)^2}= \dfrac{x(Aa)+Ab+B}{(ax+b)^2}\]


Key Point

A repeated linear factor \((ax+b)^2\) in the denominator produces two partial fractions:

\[\dfrac{A}{ax+b} + \dfrac{B}{(ax+b)^2}\]


Once again the unknown constants are found by either equating coefficients and/or substituting specific values for \(x\).
